summary: The Project Manager opened the meeting by reviewing the decisions from the previous meeting (to use voice recognition instead of the touch screen, to hide the complicated features, and to start building the prototype). The User Interface Designer and the Industrial Designer then presented the prototype that featured voice recognition, interchangeable cases, visible light, and a soft casing material. The Project Manager presented what each component cost, which showed that the project was going over the alotted budget; the group decided to remove the solar panel. The Marketing Expert presented an evaluation of the prototype and showed that the prototype had met many of the initial goals. The group then evaluated the project process and discussed their effectiveness as a group. The Project Manager summarized the proceedings of the meeting which will go into a final report, along with comments made during the project evaluation.
actions: The Project Manager will create a final report containing the summary of the meeting proceedings, including the evaluation of the project process.
decisions: The group decided to remove the solar panel in order to keep the price point of the device close to the original goal. The designers of the prototype decided to use several different colors in the visible light stream in the device. They also decided to use classic rubber buttons instead of more costly scroll buttons.
problems: The group encountered a problem with a lack of information about their specific tasks. They also felt it difficult to bring creativity to the project because of the budget constraints.

This document was truncated here because it was created in the Evaluation Mode.

Final Report



	The goal of our project was to create a Remote Control that would sell for 25 Euro and cost 12.5 Euro to make, per unit. Within these broad constraints and the specific constraints that we would include the company logo, no ‘Teletext’ technology, and that it would be TV-specific, there was a great deal of freedom.

	Ideas matured through healthy discussion and collection of data by the Marketing Expert, User Interface, and Industrial Designers. The process of decision making was reasonably democratic in the opinion of the Project Manager, but it is certainly possible that the Team Members had different opinions.

	There was considerable confusion about precisely what each individual was supposed to do between the ‘Function,’ ‘Concepts’ and ‘Detailed’ design phases, but this is largely due to the dynamic nature of the project.

	Ultimately, we were successful in designing a remote control, but we had to scrap the solar power idea for budgetary reasons.



Closing comments were largely positive. We all felt that it was a productive use of time.

-None of us used the whiteboard at all, possibly because we were hesitant to get up with the microphones on. On the other hand, the paper was used extensively, as most of us were really interested in the pens and their function. 

-the powerpoint templates were invaluable but some complained of only receiving blank slides. I received a full template, however, and the others commented that there was a large difference between how my presentations looked compared to theirs, almost certainly due to the template.

-we all had a good time roleplaying though I felt that I got too into it. The others were more able to keep reality and role separate. Perhaps because I play too many PC video games and have experience with role playing games? 

-we thought that in a real team more brainstorming would occur, perhaps if the stakes were higher?

-It was also generally held that initial stress and workload were higher than later on in the day.

-there was some confusion about what actions the ‘designers’ were supposed to take in between meetings

-all were satisfied with the level of democracy and leadership in the group and all felt that there was a large number of opportunities for creativity. However, no one necessarily broached this topic directly, it had to asked by myself, so reactions could be unreliable.

-the UID felt there was too much emphasis on his role

Concepts Meeting 



Opening remarks were made as well as auto-criticism by the P.M.

Presentations were made by all team members (see below for details)

Agreement was reached on what specific audience we’d target and what this RC would offer

Future assignments and prototype development were mentioned and begun





Industrial Designer: 

	-manufacturer has limited us to the number of materials available, it is possible that we could find another

	-there are issues of power source, chip count for touchscreen, and the option of visible light as an output as well as just infrared

	-it was recommended that we use a non-touchscreen, solar powered remote



Marketing Expert: 

	-‘Fancy,’ sleek design is in, and there is a recent interest in earth tones and a ‘natural’ look. 

	-it was recommended that the remote have a ‘squishy’ feel to the touch as this is popular amongst our target audience



User-Interface Designer: 

	-voice recognition is available in-house and so would require little to develop

	-advanced functionality is available as well and is similar to market standards, should we decide to incorporate it

	-it was recommended that the remote be ipod-sized with voice recognition and included recognizable colours and shapes



3. It was agreed that we’d develop a remote with voice recognition that had a non-remote-like shape.

	-the design should be simple with a slide or fold-out bay for advanced functions



4. The UID and ID were tasked to begin a prototype with these constraints in mind.

Detailed Design Minutes   -- Real Reaction 14/02/05



Present: Ron – User Interface Designer

	Nathan – Industrial Designer

	Sara – Marketing Expert

	Marty – Project Manger



Minutes from the last minute were summarized

The prototype for the RC was presented

Finances for the RC were discussed and recalculated to fit within general budget constraints – the solar cell was dropped in favour of just a battery to come in under budget.

Project Evaluation by Team Members was carried out

Initial Ideas



International: Universal

-possible functions,  build into other appliances?

-trade-off between size and functionality (crowding for multifunction)

-touch-screen remote, multiformat 

-material quality, ‘slickness’ 

-faceplates for the remote, possible similarities to PDAs, but no syluses

-paging button to help find remotes

-who are we marketing this for? Who’s going to use it? 

-trade-off between money and function.

Minutes from Functional Design Meeting



An Agenda was presented

Board Guidelines were presented and brief comments were made about their importance to this project

Findings from each team member were presented (see sub-sections below)

Questions for the future direction of the project were asked

Discussion was held 





Presentation by Nathan, Industrial Designer

	-pointed out safety and functional difficulties with metal casings for remote controls

	-suggested that we adopt plastic cases

	-explained function of remote controls 



Presentation by Ron, User Interface Designer

	-pointed out the cluttered design of most remote controls

	-emphasized simplicity and minimization of function

	-suggested strongly that we focus our design on novelty and maturity



Presentation by Sarah, Marketing Expert

	-most users only use the basic functions of remote controls

	-younger population is interested in voice recognition

	-current remote controls do not match function to behaviour



4. Future Directions

	It was conclude that we should focus this project on creating an RC that would be marketed to a younger audience primarily. We will look into incorporating touch screen technology and focus on simpler functions rather than attempt to please all customers.

	Image and cost will be of primary importance and finding a balance between these two polarities will be the ultimate aim for this project. Corporate restrictions will be met.
